string_table.name: pxabnsnfns00001100111
string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

slidelink.displaytext: Your role in the AIIMS control structure

search.slidetext: start topic start topic start topic the safety and success of activities hinges on the command and communications systems that are set up to control the incident. systems maintain safety at an incident scene

incident management systems you will never be working alone at an incident, regardless of its size or the type of incident a structured approach to incident management helps ensure everyone is working in a unified manner towards the safe resolution of the incident.

victorian emergency management systems you will never be working alone at an incident, regardless of its size or the type of incident cfa is nominated as a control agency for various types of incidents in the country area of victoria, including: fires and explosions, hazardous materials or dangerous goods incidents, pollution of inland waters, road accident and industrial rescue in cfa gazetted areas.

support agencies systems support agencies have specialist capacity to assist the control agency in the management and combat of an incident. cfa is a nominated support agency for: bushfire on public land (delwp control) flood and storm events (ses control) emergency medical response – emr(ambulance victoria control) urban search & rescue – usar(mfb/ses control)

aiims systems all incidents controlled by cfa are managed using the principals of the australasian inter-service incident management system (aiims): click on each image below to reveal more. flexibility flexibility flexibility flexibility flexibility flexibility management by objectives management by objectives management by objectives management by objectives management by objectives management by objectives functional management functional management functional management functional management functional management functional management span of control span of control span of control span of control span of control span of control unity of command unity of command unity of command unity of command unity of command unity of command

the aiims control structure systems incident control incident control incident control incident control incident control incident control safety safety safety safety safety safety planning planning planning planning planning planning intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence public information public information public information public information public information public information operations operations operations operations operations operations investigations investigations investigations investigations investigations investigations logistics logistics logistics logistics logistics logistics finance finance finance finance finance finance each functional unit within the structure has clear tasks and duties to perform. which unit you will be reporting to will be dependant on the tasks you are being asked to undertake. click on each functional unit to reveal more.

the aiims control structure systems incident control incident control incident control incident control incident control incident control safety safety safety safety safety safety planning planning planning planning planning planning intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence intelligence public information public information public information public information public information public information operations operations operations operations operations operations investigations investigations investigations investigations investigations investigations logistics logistics logistics logistics logistics logistics finance finance finance finance finance finance

incident communications systems everyone at an incident must maintain communication with their supervisor. this may be via radio, phone or direct contact. you must have an established communications plan back to the incident management unit you are working for to ensure that you receive vital incident information, such as red flag warnings. to manage your own safety, you must receive a briefing regarding the conditions at the incident before you deploy.

red flag warnings systems any communications plan must ensure all personnel in the field have access to vital safety information, such as ‘red flag warnings’. these will be issued by command personnel. red flag warnings can be disseminated by any appropriate means including: radio telephone written notice (fax, email etc.) verbal download jo.311 download jo.311 download jo.311 download jo.311

red flag warnings - format systems any person, to crew leader level, who receives and/or forwards a red flag warning are required to log: who communicated the red flag warning the time it was received what information it contained; how it was received (e.g. telephone, radio etc.) who you disseminated it on to; and the time acknowledgements were received from those you supervise. "red flag warning from (name, position). all personnel are advised of (actual / forecast where appropriate) conditions that may present a hazard to personnel as follows: (actual / forecast conditions). all personnel are to take this information into account in determining strategy, tactics and deployment. this warning is to be passed to all personnel under your command and is current up to_____ hrs. __/__/__. acknowledgement is required."

example – red flag warning systems in this case, the operations officer is issuing a red flag warning for a potential hazard within his area of control. "red flag warning from (name, position). all personnel are advised of (actual / forecast where appropriate) conditions that may present a hazard to personnel as follows: (actual / forecast conditions). all personnel are to take this information into account in determining strategy, tactics and deployment. this warning is to be passed to all personnel under your command and is current up to_____ hrs. __/__/__. acknowledgement is required." operations officer crew leader listen to red flag warning listen to red flag warning listen to red flag warning listen to red flag warning listen to red flag warning listen to red flag warning

smeacs safety supervisors at all levels of the incident management structure are to use the briefing format identified by the acronym smeacs. this format is to be used for all types of briefings to ensure relevant details under the following headings are passed on. click on each image below to reveal more. s s s s s s m m m m m m e e e e e e a a a a a a c c c c c c s s s s s s

after action review (aar) systems following completion of your task, it is important to debrief to pass on information regarding: how the planned tasks actually went, any unreported hazards that you encountered, any accidents and near misses, issues or suggested improvements that may affect others doing similar work. cfa uses an after action review (aar) process to enable personnel to debrief with there supervisors at the end of a incident tasking or shift download aar download aar download aar download aar

start scenario start scenario start scenario in this scenario you will asked to observe a smeacs briefing and take notes. at the end of this briefing, you will be asked to recall vital information relating to situation, mission, execution, administration command and safety of the incident responce scenario – smeacs safety
smeacs scenario safety placeholder. video and questions to be developed.
by completing this scenario, you have : [to be developed] this now concludes “topic 5: systems” congratulations. scenario complete! safety
start topic start topic start topic personal safety and the safety of others must take priority over all other activities. safety maintain safety at an incident scene

insert heading here safety you must be attired with the appropriate ppc/pe for the task being performed before entering the fire/incident ground. only perform tasks when ppc and pe being worn matches the risk environment. wear ppc and pe during training. the ensemble is to be appropriate to the training.

the safe person approach (spa) safety there are two components to managing safety during an emergency. the first component is the safe person approach (spa) there are two elements to the safe person approach. these are: responsibility the organisation has to its personnel; and responsibility that each individual has to the organisation, themselves and those around them. organisational responsibilities personal responsibilities click on the question marks below, to find out more
understanding the dra safety

bushfire protective clothing ensemble safety label the diagram. drag the protection descriptors on the right of the screen and drop on the relevant ppc item. once you are happy with your choices, hit the submit button, lower. falling objects falling objects falling objects sharp objects and hot surfaces sharp objects and hot surfaces sharp objects and hot surfaces ash and airborne particles ash and airborne particles ash and airborne particles radiant heat and lacerations radiant heat and lacerations radiant heat and lacerations chemicals, heat, ankle protection chemicals, heat, ankle protection chemicals, heat, ankle protection

laces safety in some emergencies, as conditions change, firefighters rely on the use of safety zones and timely use of escape routes for safety. in these situations laces provides a system to maintain safety. laces is used where there is a risk of burnover, of entrapment, or of a weather change increasing tree hazard. click on each image below to reveal more. l l l l l l a a a a a a c c c c c c e e e e e e s s s s s s

risk assessment matrix - likelihood safety likelihood is about how sure we are that a risk event will happen. likelihood, on its own, is not sufficient to assess the overall level of risk. so we also need to consider consequence that might result from each of likelihood descriptors.

survival with heavy machinery entrapment & survival if threatened by a fire when working with heavy machinery – bulldozers, graders or similar equipment: if possible, radio a “mayday” message. clear an area to mineral earth around the machine. turn on lights & leave the machine running. set park brake and lower attachments. shelter in the cabin or preferably seek refuge under the machine or behind the blade.

step 4 – decide (tripping risk) your turn – perform a risk assessment what is your assessment of risk? click on the risk rating to make your selection. click on submit to receive feedback. complete the first assessment matrix, for the tripping risk. risk 1: tripping over hose risk 1: tripping over hose

by completing this scenario, you have : identified risks performed a dynamic risk assessment completed a risk assessment matrix for each risk. this now concludes “topic 2: safety” congratulations. scenario complete! safety

flexibility aiims must be adaptable to an all hazards-all agency environment. it must be able to respond to changes that occur with the evolution of an incident, both during escalation and resolution, and from a focus on response to a focus on community and agency recovery.

management objectives a process of management where the incident controller, consulting as appropriate with the incident management team and supporting agencies determines the desired outcomes of the incident.

functional management the process of structuring an organisation into sections or units based on the type of work to be performed. aiims identifies a number of critical functions that must be undertaken to manage an emergency incident effectively.

span of control a principle that must be applied in both the structuring and staffing of an incident management team. the concept relates to the number of groups or individuals that can be successfully supervised by one person.

unity of command there is one set of common objectives for all those involved in the response to an incident, leading to one consolidated plan for all responders. each subordinate should report to only one superior.

describe the weather conditions. tick the two correct answers. day day day day day day night night night night night night raining raining raining raining raining raining overcast overcast overcast overcast overcast overcast
in total, how many patients were there? three. three. three. three. three. three. four. four. four. four. four. four. one. one. one. one. one. one. two. two. two. two. two. two.

which statement represents the status of these patients? two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. two were ejected, one was trapped. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. three were ejected. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. one was ejected, two were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped. three were trapped.

how was the scene secured? tick the three correct answers. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. police tape. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. emergency vehicle to prevent access. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. witches hats. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public. members of the public.

where was debris present? tick the two correct answers. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. in the culvert. road side. road side. road side. road side. road side. road side. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road. on the road.

describe the vehicle. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green commodore. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light green falcon. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue commodore. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon. light blue falcon.
what type of fuel? diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. diesel. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. lpg. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol. petrol.

what is the location? browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. browns road, noble park north. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, noble park south. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. greens road, springvale north. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south. browns road, springvale south.
what is the status of the fire? out. out. out. out. out. out. going well. going well. going well. going well. going well. going well. contained. contained. contained. contained. contained. contained.

where did the fire start? under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. under the bonnet. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. in the passenger compartment. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. outside the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle. under the vehicle.

what injuries did the driver sustain? tick all that are true. burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands burns to his hands smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. smoke inhalation. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. burns to his torso. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. lacerations to his hands. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face. chemical burns to his face.

what should you do to attend to the driver’s medical needs? tick all that are true. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. administer first aid. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. cal 000. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. send him home. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. direct him to the local gp. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital. suggest that he takes himself to hospital.
who called 000? the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. the driver. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness. a witness.
